sec.p: The most common variety is Thymus vulgaris L. It belongs to the genus Thymus of the Lamiaceae family. The EO extracted from T. vulgaris EO showed antimicrobial activity against several phytopathogens such as B. cinerea, Penicillium italicum Wehmer, P. citrophthora Leonian, and Rhizopus stolonifer (Ehrenb.) Vuill. [ 37].

Thymus species are used as food plants by the larvae of some Lepidoptera (butterfly and moth) insect species, including Chionodes distinctella and the Coleophora case-bearers C. lixella, C. niveicostella, C. serpylletorum, and C. struella [ 38]. The main single constituents of T. vulgaris EO have been listed in Table 2.
